problems.title: Cord-Cutting Crisis: Accelerating Decline of Traditional Television Subscriptions
problems.description: The television industry faces an existential crisis as cord-cutting accelerates at unprecedented rates. By the end of 2026, 75% of U.S. households with a TV will no longer have a traditional TV subscription. Nielsen data from May 2025 showed streaming platforms commanding 44.8% of total TV viewership, surpassing the combined share of broadcast (20.1%) and cable (24.1%) for the first time in history. The U.S. cable network industry has formally entered the 'decline stage of its life cycle' according to S&P Global analysis. Over 54.3 million U.S. households are projected to cut cable subscriptions by 2026, with 80.7 million households expected to use non-pay TV services. The average cable network saw its subscriber base erode by 7.1% to just 31.4 million homes in 2024. This mass exodus is driven by high prices (80% cite cost as primary reason), fewer compelling original programs on cable, and the convenience of streaming alternatives. The decline threatens the entire traditional TV ecosystem including local affiliates, regional sports networks, and news operations that depend on carriage fees and bundled distribution.
problems.summary: By end of 2026, 75% of TV households will lack traditional subscriptions as streaming overtakes linear TV for the first time, with 54.3 million households cutting the cord.

problems.title: Television Audience Measurement Fragmentation: The Cross-Platform Currency Crisis
problems.description: The television industry's measurement infrastructure has fractured beyond repair as viewing fragments across dozens of platforms and devices. Nielsen, the century-old measurement monopoly, has lost accreditation and credibility after significant undercounting of pandemic-era viewing. The single currency model that enabled simple ad buying and selling has broken down. Today's fragmented measurement landscape makes planning, implementing, and validating cross-platform campaigns overly complex and increasingly less predictable. Multiple competing measurement providers now exist - panel-based (Nielsen, Comscore), ACR-based (iSpot.TV, Samba TV, TVision), and hybrid approaches (VideoAmp) - each producing different numbers. Streaming now commands 42%+ of TV share but measurement across Netflix, YouTube, and dozens of other platforms remains inconsistent. Traditional panels struggle with niche programming where lower ratings create unreliable measurement. The lack of unified measurement undermines advertiser confidence, makes content valuation inconsistent, and prevents accurate attribution of marketing spend across the television ecosystem.

problems.title: ATSC 3.0 NextGen TV Transition Stalled: Technical and Adoption Barriers
problems.description: The broadcast television industry's transition to ATSC 3.0 (NextGen TV) has stalled due to multiple technical, regulatory, and market barriers. While promising 4K HDR video, immersive audio, and interactive features, the new standard faces critical challenges. Major TV manufacturers Samsung and LG dropped NextGen TV tuner support from many 2024 models, creating a chicken-and-egg problem where consumers can't receive broadcasts and broadcasters can't justify investment. External ATSC 3.0 tuners cost $90-$149, too expensive for mass adoption. The NAB has proposed phasing out legacy ATSC 1.0 signals by 2028 in major markets with complete transition by 2030, but current simulcasting requirements strain broadcaster spectrum and resources. DRM requirements in ATSC 3.0 have created controversy, as copy protection on free over-the-air broadcasts contradicts decades of consumer expectations. The technology promises enhanced emergency alerts and datacasting revenue, but without consumer device penetration, these benefits remain theoretical. Broadcasters face a $10+ billion infrastructure investment with uncertain return on investment.

problems.title: Television Advertising Revenue Structural Decline and Market Share Erosion
problems.description: Television advertising revenue faces a structural decline as advertisers shift budgets to digital platforms with better targeting and measurement. In 2024, gross advertising revenue for cable networks fell 5.9% to $20.2 billion, the lowest level since 2007. The industry outlook anticipates a 0.2% decline in core spot ad revenue to $17.49 billion in 2025, with total TV station ad revenue projected to decline 12.5% to $21.81 billion due to absence of 2024's political and Olympics spending. While a rebound to $24.67 billion is expected in 2026 driven by midterm elections and FIFA World Cup, the underlying trend shows persistent erosion of TV's advertising market share. Digital advertising now commands the majority of ad spend, with platforms like Google, Meta, and Amazon offering superior audience targeting, real-time optimization, and performance attribution. Television's advantages in brand-building and reach are increasingly questioned as streaming fragments audiences and measurement remains problematic. The industry faces a potential death spiral where declining viewership leads to reduced ad rates, causing further budget shifts to digital.

problems.title: Smart TV Platform Gatekeeping: OEMs Control Content Discovery and User Experience
problems.description: Smart television manufacturers have become powerful gatekeepers controlling how viewers discover and access content, threatening the position of traditional broadcasters and content providers. One of the most overlooked industry challenges involves the device ecosystem where Smart TVs control the user experience, search environment, and content discovery process - not broadcasters or content networks. TV manufacturers like Samsung, LG, Roku, and Amazon (Fire TV) now determine which apps get prime home screen placement, how search results are ranked, and what content is promoted to viewers. These platforms collect valuable viewer data and command advertising revenue that previously went to content providers. Broadcasters must negotiate for placement and often pay carriage fees to be included on smart TV platforms - a reversal of the traditional cable carriage model. The platforms' recommendation algorithms can bury smaller channels and networks, making discovery nearly impossible for niche content. Free Ad-Supported Streaming TV (FAST) channels integrated into TV interfaces compete directly with broadcast channels for attention. This power shift threatens broadcaster direct relationships with audiences and could further commoditize content providers.
problems.summary: Smart TV OEMs now control content discovery, search results, and home screen placement, reversing traditional power dynamics and threatening broadcaster relationships with audiences.

problems.title: Local Television News Crisis: Declining Resources Threaten Community Journalism
problems.description: Local television news operations face a severe resource crisis threatening their ability to serve communities with essential journalism. Without federal funding, local stations are eliminating or reducing local programs, including local history programs, community event coverage, agricultural programming, and local public affairs programming. Some public television stations will go dark in June 2026 due to funding cuts. The economics of local TV news have deteriorated as cord-cutting reduces carriage fees, local advertising shifts to digital platforms, and ownership consolidation leads to cost-cutting. Station groups have implemented shared services arrangements where a single news operation serves multiple markets, reducing local focus. News deserts are expanding as stations cut back or eliminate news operations entirely in smaller markets. The crisis threatens not just journalism but essential public services including emergency alerts, severe weather coverage, and community information. Sports rights costs have further squeezed news budgets as stations pay more for local sports content. The journalism workforce has been decimated through layoffs, with experienced reporters and anchors replaced by less expensive or automated alternatives.

problems.title: Television Diversity and Representation Gaps: Persistent Inequities On and Off Screen
problems.description: The television industry continues to face significant diversity and representation challenges both on screen and behind the camera. UCLA's 10th annual Hollywood Diversity Report found that while top TV shows increasingly feature racially and ethnically diverse casts reflecting population demographics, people of color remain underrepresented as leads in broadcast and digital platforms, and actors with disabilities are clearly underrepresented across all platforms. Behind the scenes, showrunners and directors who reflect diverse identities remain underrepresented, with studies showing diversity in writers' rooms also lacking. The underrepresentation of Black talent is due in part to racial bias among industry decision makers and gatekeepers, with unconscious biases creating barriers to entry and limiting career progression. White male creators receive bigger budgets, with about half receiving more than $3 million per episode, while studios provide less funding to projects led by people of color and white women. When a Black creator leads a Netflix series, 72% of series regulars are Black, compared to 15.4% with non-Black creators, indicating Black creatives carry the burden of diversity. A McKinsey study found addressing racial inequities could generate an additional $10 billion in annual revenues for the industry.

problems.title: Sports Broadcasting Rights Fragmentation: Viewers Unable to Access Local and National Sports
problems.description: Sports broadcasting has become increasingly fragmented and inaccessible as rights are spread across multiple streaming services, cable networks, and broadcast channels. Sports may no longer be the anchor that once kept consumers from cutting the video cord, with an S&P survey finding that 90% of households dropping pay TV for sports in the past year were sports fans, and nearly two-thirds spent five or more hours per week watching sports. Regional Sports Networks (RSNs) face a systemic crisis with Diamond Sports (Bally Sports) emerging from bankruptcy and multiple teams losing their RSN coverage entirely. Fans now need multiple subscriptions to follow a single team: local games on RSN or team streaming, some games on national broadcast, others on ESPN+, Amazon, Apple TV+, or league-specific services. The 'defining challenge for 2026 will be divorce' from traditional TV, as streamers buy up sports and live events while the traditional bundle unravels. Blackout rules designed for the cable era create absurd situations where fans can't watch games despite paying for services. The fragmentation particularly harms casual fans unwilling to navigate complex subscription stacks, potentially shrinking sports audiences over time.
problems.summary: Sports rights fragmented across 10+ platforms with RSNs in crisis, as 90% of cord-cutters who left pay TV for sports were actually sports fans, showing the bundle is breaking.

problems.title: Television Production Infrastructure: Costly IP Transition and Technical Modernization
problems.description: The broadcast and media industry's ongoing technical transformation is expected to reach several inflection points in 2026. Economic pressures are forcing faster decisions on infrastructure investments as IP transitions that have been planned for years move to implementation. Television production facilities face a complex and expensive transition from legacy SDI (Serial Digital Interface) infrastructure to IP-based systems. While IP offers significant advantages in flexibility, scalability, and remote production capabilities, the transition requires substantial capital investment at a time when traditional television revenues are declining. Facilities must often run hybrid SDI/IP systems during transition, doubling complexity and costs. The industry also faces cybersecurity concerns as IP-connected production systems create new attack surfaces requiring robust security measures. Staff require retraining on IP technologies, and the shortage of engineers with IP expertise creates bottlenecks. AI applications are shifting from experimentation to operational deployment, requiring additional infrastructure investment. Many smaller stations and production facilities lack the capital and expertise to execute these transitions, potentially creating a two-tier industry of modernized and legacy operations.

problems.title: Cable Network Consolidation and Closures: Industry Restructuring Accelerates
problems.description: The cable television network landscape is undergoing rapid consolidation and closure as media conglomerates restructure for the streaming era. Building on momentum from 2025 when five major cable TV networks shuttered amid declining viewership, 2026 is poised to see even more closures as media conglomerates prioritize efficiency over breadth. Comcast finalized the spinoff of its cable networks (excluding Bravo) into a standalone entity named 'Versant' on January 2, 2026. Reports indicate Paramount is considering shutting down all of its cable networks to become a digital-only brand. Networks like Teen Nick saw viewership drop 25% in 2025 and now rank 135 out of 153 in primetime. Kids channels are particularly vulnerable as children shift to YouTube Kids and streaming services. These strategic exits signal that major media conglomerates are now willing to abandon cable networks in favor of streaming services. The closures result in job losses, reduced content diversity, and the end of established brands that served specific audiences for decades. The restructuring also creates uncertainty for cable distributors negotiating carriage agreements and advertisers planning media buys.
